I understand that they have been split to comply with various elements of section 55 of the constitution. These bills empower the Australian Communications Authority to tax the spectrum licensees for cost recovery purposes in the maintenance and management of the spectrum. Members will be aware that there is to be a new system for auctioning and licensing radiocommunications. The fact that this is to be done within the spectrum itself rather than tied to the receivers and the transmitters, as was the case in the past, is a change which I think is a step forward. In many ways, these bills try to harmonise the taxing of the spectrum and, therefore, the Labor Party will not be seeking to oppose them. Of course, we continue to support strong regulation for the spectrum to ensure that the public interest is protected-that, first of all, the public and commercial users of the spectrum know what their rights are-and that the interests of community broadcasters also are not ignored in making sure that people continue to have access to Australia's electromagnetic spectrum. I want to make a few comments about some of the consequences of this bill and some of the consequences of the proposed auctions that are mentioned in the bill. Firstly, I understand that the Australian Communications Authority is planning to run the auctions by using an online computer database with real-time bidding. The applicants will bid for packages of spectrum which fit into a particular plan. Applicants will also be issued with software and receive training on how to use the on-line computer bidding. One or two communications ministers have got into difficulty in the past in working out ways to allocate licences in communications, and pay TV of course is the obvious example. During the two years that I had the honour of being communications minister, we introduced an open auction system-an English auction system, I think, was the definition that was often used. estate. People would apply for the right to be bidders in the auction and they would have to meet certain criteria before they were given a paddle, allowing them to be bidders in the open auction system. theText: No, it was not the New Zealand model. It was a system like an auction for real7328 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 28 August 1997 for that spectrum. That is always the difficulty, making sure that the public do get a fair return from the sale of certain rights or access to spectrum. The department has been keen for a while to introduce on-line computer bidding, and I understand that it might have been trialled in the United States. I do not know how they judge the success of the auction in the United States, given that it is very hard to know how you measure the real value of something through different types of auction systems. I did have some concerns about how successful the on-line computer auction system would be and I have to say that, at the moment, my inclination would be to stick to the open auction system. But it will be interesting to watch how this government and this minister go in taking the courageous decision to move to the new system for allocating this part of the spectrum. Of course, we will be watching with interest how those auctions go. One of the bands to be auctioned includes the 800 megahertz and 1.8 gigahertz spectrum. In debates in the past I have raised my concerns about what that might mean for the community. It is my understanding-and it has been confirmed by the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Alston, in a letter to me-that the signal for these higher frequency communications devices will only travel a short distance before there are difficulties with signal strength. As a result, the next generation of mobile phones-some people call them PCS-will be using the 800 megahertz and 1.8 gigahertz system. But, as the signal will only travel half the distance, when companies purchase the rights to use this spectrum and introduce the next generation of mobile phone towers, to make that system work they will have to install twice as many mobile telephone towers as we have today. Given how much opposition there has been to date to the existing mobile telephone tower network, imagine the effect of the number of mobile telephone transponders doubling: that has to be the inevitable result of the government proceeding down the path outlined here. I am not sure if the minister has explained that to his backbench, who I understand have raised a few questions in the party room about mobile telephone towers, but perhaps at next Tuesday's meeting they might ask whether the minister has written to the opposition and told us that, in fact, there will be many more mobile telephone towers as a result of the auction for the 800 megahertz and 1.8 gigahertz system going ahead. He has certainly told us; I hope he has told you. off to the independent arbitrator-the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency-which I thought would be pretty tough on any proposals that generated controversy. I am not sure that the current system has solved some of the problems that have been raised in many communities right around Australia-in your own electorate, no doubt, as well as in mine. The simple point I am trying to make is this: imagine having twice as many towers as we have today! That will be the inevitable result of the next part of the plan going ahead. The other point I would like to make briefly is that we all know that the analog mobile telephone network is scheduled to shut down in the year 200D-at the moment I think the date will be 1 January 2000. Since we will be the first country that is holding an Olympics with a mobile telephone system which is compatible with other countries, there is going to be a real risk that our digital telephone system will collapse because of the massive demand. After all, Australians have had a reputation for a high take-up in technological matters. We have probably the highest proliferation of video cassette recorders in the world and mobile phone usage, I submit, is probably way up with the top handful of countries as well. If there are going to be 30,000 extra journalists in Sydney for the 2000 Olympics, you can imagine about 40,000 mobile phones attached to them. We can certainly see that there could be additional pressure. As long as we are not going to impose on the Australian taxpayer, and the telephone system in general, an unreal additional burden to accommodate the temporary additional usage of phones, we should be looking at some mechanism to accommodate them. The matters here today are also equally important. BeforeI go on to the bill in particular, I want to answer a couple of matters raised in the debate by the honourable member with regard to telecommunication towers. One of the things that Minister Alston has done since becoming the Minister for Communications and the Arts is to introduce and have passed the telecommunications legislation of 1997 which encourages the sharing of facilities and the sharing of towers. Whilst we have heard of the potential for proliferation of additional towers in the contribution from the honourable member, as a result of the changes which we made to the previous government's telecommunications regime there are more opportunities and demands for telecommunications carriers to co-locate. The erection of towers is now a matter for state and territory governments and local councils to determine and no longer a matter that is directly within the bailiwick of the federal government. The carriers certainly do not have the immunities that they used to have under the previous Labor government's act. It is also fair to say there are many factors that may determine the requirements as far as towers are concerned, so it is not inevitable that we will see a doubling of the number of towers. The government has addressed a lot of those matters. I only intended to speak for a few minutes on the bills themselves. I simply wanted to be associated with these new arrangements which are sensible and somewhat procedural in their nature. They are certainly straightforward enough and are not opposed by the Labor opposition. In fact, from the outset, they had their origins in a bipartisan committee suggestion in 1991 when the report Management of the radiofrequency spectrum was released by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. speaker: Mr Hardgrave (Moreton) (10.28 A.m.)
theText: I welcome the contribution by the honourableThursday, 28 August 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 7331 here this morning of the very effective chairman of our committee, the member for Lyne( Mr Vaile). What we have here is a government that is prepared to listen to private members' contributions through the committee system. Unlike the previous government, we have taken those suggestions on board and we have legislation here that is going to take those suggestions and bring them into law. There is a provision for an annual spectrum maintenance licence fee. As I said, the current government has shown itself supportive of the role of backbench members and that idea came straight from that committee years ago. The bills before us seek to apply and collect an annual spectrum licence fee and to recover spectrum maintenance costs from spectrum licences issued under the Radiocommunications Act 1992. This is not so much a new tax but simply a better form of taxing or charging or levying spectrum licensees who benefit from spectrum maintenance practices, including international coordination, domestic planning, interference investigation and policy development, carried out by what was known as the Spectrum Management Agency and since 1 July the Australian Communications Authority-the ACA. The ACA does all those different jobs on behalf of all radiocommunications licensees, so it is appropriate for spectrum licensees to contribute to the recovery of the various costs associated with access to spectrum and the services provided by the ACA by paying a proportionate share of an annual spectrum maintenance tax. It simply is a user-pays system and it is far better than the old approach which will go as a result of these bills. There has never been a spectrum based arrangement until now. Equipment licensees have been the ones to pay these various maintenance costs. These bills will tidy up inconsistencies between the licensing systems for spectrum and equipment as well as ensuring accountability via transparency, so that spectrum licensees are well aware of the ongoing costs of spectrum management they pay. This is important because the ACA will actually determine the amount of the tax that is charged, which is presently the case for apparatus licences. While there is no set maximum limit on the tax which can be imposed, there certainly are checks in the system, including powers under section 235 of the Radiocommunications Act which can be exercised by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston). This is an area of public policy which is highly flexible; it is dynamic; it is changing exponentially in so many ways. Spectrum licences can be traded, subdivided and amalgamated, which could lead to the possibility that a single licensee could hold a large proportion of spectrum in a particular band. The amendments contained in these bills enable all radio communication licensees to share the costs of the provision of an efficient spectrum management service in Australia by the new ACA. The two key things that people in communications and, in particular, in the media, want is content and also means of distribution. As far as spectrum, even for mobile technology, is concerned, people in the general media, the Packers and the Murdochs, see the role of mobile telephony and mobile technology as being part of the future as far as they and their aspirations are concerned. It is important that the government understands that a regime such as this is growing and there are all sorts of possibilities. These bills certainly provide that flexibility. Perhaps the best part about these bills is that the processes are transparent, they are accountable and there are built-in limits on the discretion of the bureaucracy administering these matters. I commend the bills to the House. 7332 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 28 August 1997 Foreign Affairs) (10.35 a.m.)-In the absence of the minister representing the minister for communications in the House of Representatives, I will make a few brief remarks to sum up the debate on the Radiocommunications (Spectrum Licence Tax) Bill 1997 and the Radiocommunications Legislation Amendment Bill 1997. As the member for Dobel1 ( Mr Lee) pointed out in the beginning of his speech, the purpose of these two bills is to harmonise the tax regime of the radiocommunications spectrum to recover the costs of the maintenance of the spectrum. When we talk about the sorts of things that comprise the maintenance of a spectrum, we can think of things such as the international coordination of it, the planning of it domestically and the investigation of interference in the spectrum. The general policy development of the spectrum had until now been carried out by the Spectrum Management Agency, which from 1 July this year became the Australian Communications Authority or the ACA. There has been a little concern, I think, that the agency has perhaps unfettered discretion in being able to set the amount of tax to be paid by users of the spectrum. This is not so, because any determination made by the agency will be a disallowable instrument and, further, under section 235 of the Radiocommunications Act 1992, the minister has power to direct the agency in relation to the performance of its functions and the exercise of those powers. The member for Dobell also adverted to some likely difficulties with the spectrum around the time of the Olympics when a lot of visitors to a certain part of Sydney are going to be carrying mobile telephones with them. He made a couple of helpful suggestions and we will take them on board. This is probably not the first time that a large number of observers, journalists or otherwise, have gathered in a particular place seeking to use mobile telephony to communicate with their home bases. I can think, for example, of the Gulf War where many of the world's media gathered to observe that conflict. My observation of that was that they brought with them the temporary capacity to transmit their messages to their communications network back home. I expect that they will have to do much the same come the Olympics because, as the member for Moreton( Mr Hardgrave) said, it is not entirely the responsibility of the Australian taxpayer, through the federal government, to provide permanent capacity for a sudden influx of such instruments into a particular part of Australia. But I am sure that that issue will be dealt with in due course both by the federal government and, hopefully, by a Collins government in the state of New South Wales. Question resolved in the affirmative. Bills read a second time. Bills-by leave-reported to the House without amendment. speaker: Mr Andrew Thomson (Wentworth
theText: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister forThursday, 28 August 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 7333 Transport, Communications and Infrastructure Committee Report Debate resumed from 27 August, on motion by Mr Reith: That the House take note of the paper. report. It is the sequel to the famous Ships of shame report and I commend the committee on producing this subsequent report with respect to this very important issue. The report reinforces the message that emerged from the original Ships of shame inquiry, namely that the operation of particular vessels in Australian coastal waters produces some very serious problems that Australia has yet to fully address. These problems include extreme exploitation of workers. Workers are sometimes bashed, denied food, put in outrageous circumstances, deprived of wages or, when they are paid, they are paid at an extremely low level. Some of the horrific stories that have emerged with respect to the treatment of workers on many of the vessels that ply Australian and international waters are of great concern. They are Dickensian circumstances that in most of the world-certainly in Western world economic activity-were eliminated a long time ago with, perhaps, one or two exceptions such as certain types of outwork. The prevalence of ships of shame exposes us to very serious safety problems. The reports of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority indicate that there are a substantial number of ships serving in the Australian industry internationally and registered in flag of convenience states that regularly have very serious safety deficiencies that inevitably, from time to time, result in disaster. These deficiencies are of particular concern not only for the lives of those on board the vessels but also, in certain circumstances, for those in the immediate vicinity if the vessels are in port-for example, the risk of fire could be a serious hazard to others, apart from the crewmen on the vessel. The environmental concerns are particularly of great concern to Australia as a nation. We have got such a vast coastline, and so much of that coastline is of extreme importance to our tourism industry and the broader environment. The Great Barrier Reef is an obvious example, but is one of only a number of examples. In recent times we have had disasters, such as the Sanko Harvest and the Kirki, that indicate just how serious these threats are and the sort of damage that could be done to our marine environment and our tourism industry by a disaster involving a flag of convenience vessel: the possibilities really beggar the imagination. These are very serious issues for Australia. Thus far, in spite of the best efforts of AMSA, which does do a very good job in inspecting vessels and enforcing regulations, we have failed to fully grapple with the issue. In that context, as the shadow minister for transport I and the opposition generally have considerable concerns with respect to the recommendations of the recent inquiry which is still the subject of discussions between the minister and the various parties interested in Australian shipping. It proposes to abolish cabotage. This means that the extent to which flag of convenience vessels, and foreign registered vessels generally, will be able to operate in

speaker: Mr Tanner (Melbourne) (10.41 A.m.)
theText: I wish to make some very brief remarks on this7334 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 28 August 1997 Australian waters will be significantly increased because domestic routes will be opened up to foreign involvement. So initially we have a concern that, as well as vessels engaged in international trade being a serious risk to the Australian environment and to workers engaged on them-and to the Australian community generally-we will have a situation where vessels of that type will also be able to trade in the domestic Australian shipping industry. This is of particular concern because in reality this amounts to the first introduction of guest workers into the Australian economy, something that is common in many parts of the world, particularly in the Middle East and in some parts of Europe. What it means is that foreign workers, paid perhaps $200 a week or maybe less-but very unlikely to be much more and substantially less than the equivalent rate for Australian workers-will be able to work in the domestic Australian transport industry. The fundamental flaw with the notion of abolishing cabotage is that you cannot really stop there. If you are running a trucking company or a private rail line or even a charter aviation company, and the domestic shipping industry is able to employ foreign workers at substantially lower rates of pay than the Australian award rates, then it is difficult to see why you should be discriminated against and why you should not be able to do the same thing. The inevitable logic of allowing the open slather employment of foreign workers at a fraction of the rate that is provided for in the Australian award in domestic shipping is that you do the same thing for people who are driving trucks or driving trains or flying planes on the equivalent route because, even though there is a distinction between the freight task that is performed, there is a substantial competitive overlap. That can be seen in numerous examples. In the choices that are made by people who ship cargo there is a substantial competitive overlap. So if there is a change in the balance favourable to shipping because it can employ people at much, much cheaper rates than the standard Australian award rates, the end result is that there will be a shift. Others who compete with shipping in different transport modes, particularly in rail but also to a lesser extent road transport, will then be entitled to say, 'If they can have cheap foreign labour, why can't we?' Australia has a labour market regulatory structure that applies to our domestic economy. Shipping between Australian ports is part of our domestic transport system, part of our domestic economy, and should therefore be part of our domestic labour market regulatory structure. In closing, I will just refer to a few of the recommendations of this sequel to the Ships of shame report, and I certainly would urge the government to pay very careful considerations to them. One recommendation in the report is that ILO convention 147 should be ratified by the government. I would certainly support that. The report also recommends a detailed system of inspection for vessels whose owners are applying for single voyage permits or continuous voyage permits, which provide the flexibility in the cabotage arrangements and which mean a significant number of foreign vessels are plying our coast in the domestic trade where no domestic ship is available. This should only occur after a thorough examination and inspection of the vessel concerned to ensure that it is safe and that you do not have a serious environmental disaster or safety hazard to those on board or to other parties. Another recommendation is that insurance requirements applying to shipping be tightened to ensure that the protection for the Australian community is maximised. Thursday, 28 August 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 7335 I commend the committee for its work on the report. I certainly believe the government should take its recommendations seriously and it should not implement the recommendations of the Manser report with respect to the abolition of cabotage. I believe that would be contrary to the whole notion of labour market regulation in Australia. We are a nation of citizens who have certain rights and obligations with respect to our labour that do not apply to non-Australian citizens, people who are domiciled in other countries, other than through appropriate mechanisms-through immigration law and visas and the like. I commend the report to the committee and to the government. Debate (on motion by Mr Andrews) adjourned. ANL LIMITED Report Debate resumed from 27 August, on motion by Mr Reith: That the House take note of the paper. with respect to the annual report of the Australian National Line. It is of some interest because the ANL has been controversial in the past few years, and it is worth making note in the parliament of its progress in recent times. It is vital to understand the background to the ANL's current circumstances, the history of the organisation and also the changing climate in which it has to operate. The genesis of ANL emerged from the need by our young nation 60 or 70 years ago to stand up for itself against the monopolistic or cartel characteristics of British shipping lines. In those days, of course, they dominated world shipping. ANL was a very important means of ensuring that Australia was not being charged grossly excessive shipping prices by British shipping lines. It was not favoured by the conservative parties at the time, because in many respects they had formal and informal links with the people in Britain who owned the shipping lines. ANL and its predecessor had a difficult task staying in existence because of the general opposition of the conservatives, but nonetheless played a very valuable role. ANL was also important in ensuring that transport links, particularly freight links, were maintained with various remote parts of Australia that at that stage were not served by adequate road networks: certain parts of Queensland, Western Australia and, indeed, across Bass Strait. It had a task that in a sense has been outgrown because of the development of other transport modes: aviation, road transport, rail transport and the like. Decades went by without an acknowledgment of that changing task, or the fact that these two aspects of ANL' s origins were no longer particularly relevant. In recent years there has been a glut of international shipping because of the break-up of the Soviet Union and the change in economic orientation of China. This has meant that the international shipping arena is becoming increasingly cut throat, to the detriment of ANL. In a sense, international shipping is a gigantic international tax avoidance industry. All sorts of extraordinary activities go on there. The desperation for getting cargo and the desperation of seamen from ThirdW orId countries to get work, sometimes in the most appalling circumstances, have acted to shift the competitive balance substantially adversely to ANL and to Australian seamen. For many years these issues were not addressed, but they surfaced in a very stark way in the early nineties. ANL continued on largely unchanged for many years, but the impact started

theText: I would like to make some quick observations7336 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 28 August 1997 to emerge in the early to mid-nineties. To his credit, the former Minister for Transport, the member for Kingsford-Smith( Mr Brereton) bit the bullet and addressed these problems in 1994-95. In particular, he established a new board for ANL which was charged with refocusing the organisation, turning around its deteriorating finances and reforming its whole approach. Certainly there were some significant question marks about how ANL had been administered in the period prior to the intervention by the then Minister for Transport. I do not mean administration by previous ministers, but internally. Some matters clearly needed to be addressed with respect to budgeting and dealing with particular routes and a variety of other factors. It is interesting to note that prior to dealing with abnormals, the operating loss for ANL in this annual report for 1995-96 is $11 million. That is not necessarily a particularly happy state of affairs, but it is certainly an improvement on the preceding year's $19 million. It is interesting to note that Mr Kym Bills from the department said recently in Senate estimates that the 1996-97 loss, which presumably we will have details of in the near future, is expected to be halved again. If we are seeing a pattern in a $19 million loss going down to a $11 million loss, down to a $5 or $6 million loss, at least it is heading in the right direction. The changes that were introduced by the then Minister for Transport, the member for Kingsford-Smith, much as they have been criticised both then and in recent times by the then opposition-now the government-are paying dividends. The organisation has been turned around. The necessary hard decisions have been made and ANL is getting back on an equal footing. Even if abnormals are included-and it is interesting to note that this is the standard practice by the current minister when dealing with Australian National, our national railway corporation-the drop in the loss has been from $30.9 million in 1994-95 to $6.3 million in $1995-96. If abnormals are included, the reduction in the loss is even more stark. I would like to congratulate the new board and management of ANL for turning around the organisation over that period of time. It was desperately needed and quite clearly there is a major change in direction and a streamlining of the organisation that has actually started to pay dividends. It is interesting to note that, in opposition, the current Minister for Transport and Regional Development ( Mr Sharp) attacked the Labor government for failing to address ANL's problems and for failing to do anything. He has been in government now close to 18 months and over that time his track record of doing anything with respect to ANL stands at precisely zero. The coalition has made mutterings about selling ANL. We are yet to see any action on that front and, in some respects, I hope that he continues to do nothing. Given his track record, it is likely that any intervention on his part will actually make things worse. As things stand at the moment, the board and management are getting the organisation back on track to a point where it does have some future, albeit as a niche player and potentially, I suspect, as a player in alliance with a larger international shipping company. I suspect that the ultimate pattern that will emerge in international shipping is going to reflect what is happening in international aviation, where you will see alliances emerge, based on particular market strengths, between larger and smaller players. It would certainly be logical for ANL to become a niche player that is connected with a larger international shipping company, so that some of the problems that ANL has with backloading, for example, because Thursday, 28 August 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 7337 of the configuration of our exports and imports being so different, can potentially be addressed as a result of arrangements with other allies in the shipping industry. We do have to concede that ANL's future is very much problematic because of its size. I met with leaders of the Chinese shipping company, Cosco, or its manifestation in Australia, Five Star Shipping, late last year-from memory. In complete innocence, they asked me how many ships our national shipping line had and told me how many ships their national shipping line had. My answer to their question was six, I think, at the time. Their answer to me was 868 which is a good indication of the difficulty that ANL faces in the international shipping arena, when it has got players of that size competing against it. It has clearly only got a niche role to play. Nonetheless, there are significant possibilities there that I think we should be exploring. I commend the report to the committee and commend the management, staff and workers of ANL and the new board for having achieved a very substantial improvement over the last year or two. I trust that that improvement will continue. Debate (on motion by Mr Andrews) adjourned. They are a credit to their office. I have had the pleasure of dealing personally with the airworthiness inspectors while setting up my own maintenance facility. They were most helpful. Their attention to detail and their requirement that every detail was met may seem to some a bureaucratic nightmare and far too much red tape, but aviation maintenance is one field where any lacks, breaches or poor workmanship can mean a complete accident and, of course, destruction of the aircraft. I commend the people in the Brisbane office for their efforts. They do a mighty job and they are a real credit to the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. The regulators need muscle to be effective, and the thrust of this government is to give them teeth. As far as I am concerned, the minister has done a mighty job in tidying up the industry. You can obviously see from dealing with and talking with surveyors, inspectors and some of the people in the senior management of CAS A and, of course, airworthiness as well, that people are trying to adjust and trying to get their industry up to date and on track. I commend the minister and I thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker, for this opportunity. are debating this morning is an attempt by the Minister for Transport, the honourable John Sharp, to redirect the Civil Aviation Safety Authority and air safety regulation in this country. This task is important to all Australians. Aviation safety matters not just to pilots and passengers and those who live under the flight paths but, indeed, to the reputation of our country, to the security that we all need as regular passengers, and to those who need to use the services of the aviation industry. Regulatory arrangements are important to guarantee this safety, but it is difficult to know of a regulatory body anywhere that has been subjected to such universal disapproval as the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. Sometimes they have to do things that are tough in the state or national interest, but everyone expects that those decisions will be made with a degree of compassion, wisdom, and particularly accuracy. It has been the incapacity of CASA to act consistently and reliably that has caused such concern. We need a regulatory body that is competent and that people have confidence in. It has been a sad reflection on the board of CASA and its administrators, particularly in the early life of this government, that they have devoted most of their time, it seems, to arguing with the minister, unwilling to recognise that he was determined to make changes. Some of the board members seemed to be more interested in protecting their own position than in

speaker: Mr Truss (Wide Bay) (11.04 A.m.)
theText: The statement on aviation safety regulation that weThursday, 28 August 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 7339 ensuring the competence of safety regulation in this country. They have treated the government with contempt. The chairman is still in position, even though it has been made abundantly clear to him that the government wishes him to resign. There seems to be this interest in personal positions rather than caring for regulation of safety in Australia. This is a matter of serious concern. In the past, there has been a lot of criticism of laxness in policy administration and several serious air incidents in Australia have been attributed in no small way to the inadequacies of CAS A. It has been an organisation which has a long record of discord and disharmony. The minister himself commented in the House, prior to becoming a minister, on the Monarch air situation. He said: The CAA has obviously fallen down in its prime responsibility to conduct safety regulation of civil air operations in Australia. It has no excuses. The CAA has been given the teeth. The problem is that they are not using them. In the Plane safe inquiry chaired by Mr Morris, the preface is an appalling indictment of the culture that existed in CASA at the time. It says: The inquiry has been characterised by personality conflict, unsubstantiated allegations, a venom and viciousness not experienced by committee members in previous inquiries. A little later in the preface, it states: The report reveals a regulator at war with itself and under constant attack from vested interests within the general aviation and commuter industry. This is really a very serious indictment of what has been happening within our aviation regulator. It is natural, therefore, that any government that is serious about its responsibilities will want to act to ensure that something is done about improving safety regulation in this country. There has been change within CASA not only with the appointment of extra and new board members but also in the attitudes of the administrative body. I am not sure that they are all for the better. There is a determination within some elements of CASA to vigorously enforce petty regulations. In fact, one person, who deals regularly with CAS A in these sorts of matters, described what is happening in CASA at the present time as 'a campaign of administrative brutality.' CASA seems to be spending a great deal of time on trivial paperwork offences-desperate, it seems, to get up the number of breaches that it identifies-but most of these are in such trivial areas that they are not a threat to passenger safety. They merely increase the score for the authority. I am told that recently they spent two days in court, after lengthy investigations, and achieved at the end a $400 fine-while at the same time there continue to be complaints about matters that really are worthy of serious investigation. I am concerned that the Civil Aviation Safety Authority is spending its time on trivial paperwork matters which, whilst they should never be ignored, are not fundamental to dealing with aviation safety issues. I also remain concerned about the quality, training and experience of many of the regulators themselves. It seems to me that, on many occasions, CAS A staff are placed in the position of supervising the activities of people who have experience vastly greater than, and training vastly superior to, that which the regulators themselves have received. Flying operations inspectors get 39 hours training time per annum-vastly less than those who are actually operating in the industry-yet they are the people who are supervising the pilots and the aviation industry. 7340 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 28 August 1997 There have been many instances reported of supposed flying operator inspectors indicating breaches when in fact, on further scrutiny, it has been found that people were not breaking the laws at all. There have been issued many notices of non-compliance which later had to be withdrawn because they simply were not non-compliant. I appreciate that the aviation regulations are complex and difficult to decipher-and, some people say, self-contradictory from time to time. But if in fact our inspectors are not able to understand them, how can ordinary operators within the industry know what is going on? A constituent told me of an example of a flying operations inspector for CASA seeking to hire one of his helicopters but having insufficient recent operating experience for the constituent to be willing to entrust his helicopter to the CASA official. Yet, the next day, this inspector is supervising helicopter pilots in this country and assessing whether they are competent to operate. There are still serious problems in ensuring that CASA attracts appropriately qualified staff to be able effectively to do the work that is assigned to them. It is of course essential that the Civil Aviation Safety Authority have substantial powers. It must have the capacity to ground an airline if there are serious safety breaches. It must have the capacity, without having to wait for court orders and the like, to act immediately if passengers are at risk. On the other hand, CAS A has the power to ground operators for mere technical breaches or matters that are perhaps of little substance; and that is a matter of concern. I am concerned that operators have their licences removed for trivial matters and are left incomeless and with no capacity to have their circumstances reviewed in the short term. Once charges are laid, they go to court, and of course it can take many months before matters are finally determined. But, in that period, the operator may have no licence and therefore will not be able to operate. It seems to me that there is a denial of natural justice when a licence is removed and a pilot or operator has no capacity to have that action immediately reviewed. This is something that needs to be examined in the legislation. There must be a capacity for somebody who has their licence removed to be able to appeal and get an immediate determination on whether that action is reasonable. It is no good-six months later, when charges are dismissed in courttelling the man he can have his licence back, if his business has already been lost. This is really 'guilty until proven innocent' stuff that has no place in the Australian system of justice and fair play. These are matters that clearly need to be reviewed. I would also like to refer to some of the other problems that are occurring and are regularly being brought to members' attention in relation particularly to the examination system for new pilots. In this area there are a number of matters of serious concern. Mr Bill Hamilton, the new President of the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association of Australia, has written to all members expressing concern about the new examination papers. He said: It's pretty lucky that we have the expression "on a wing and a prayer"; because a prayer is exactly what you will need if you are going to sit for the IFR WRITTEN EXAM. CASA is at it again; bad organisation, poor airrnanship and absolutely hopeless administration. In the last year the IFR WRITTEN EXAM pass mark has gone down to as little as 10% of the candidates-Why? BECAUSE CASA IS FAILING CANDIDATES WHO OUGHT TO PASS. They are doing it with bad questions and bungling the answers in company with a computer marking reader that can't read the answers! This is no way to maintain safety standards. AOPA has asked major teaching organisations in four States of Australia and the whole sorry story is the same all over the country. Bad questions, ambiguous answers. Many of the flying schools said that the questions could not be answered by properly trained candidates. Thursday, 28 August 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 7341 CASA won't tell anyone what the exam questions are, so we can only guess about what is asked but when CAS A gave us an example of their questions, they can't even get it right themselves! He then referred to answers in the CAS A Flight Safety Australia autumn 1997 magazine. He went on to say: Four choices are offered as the correct answer to Question7 and three of them are right (it just depends on where you are in the approach). How do you pick the correct one? Guesswork? That's great isn't it if your exam pass, or your son's or daughter's, depends on it. It is almost unbelievableAnd the letter goes on. So there are serious concerns about the quality of the examination system that is being provided. I would like to refer to another example brought to my attention where a helicopter instructor was required by CASA to test his own son for a commercial helicopter licence. The instructor objected and said that this was completely inappropriate, but CAS A insisted that he test his own son for a helicopter licence. That seems to me to lack procedural fairness, to put it mildly. Yet that was a requirement of CASA in the examination system. So we still have a very long way to go. Mr Bill Hamilton in his comments on this issue made the observation: I am seriously concerned about the harm the Civil Aviation Safety Authority is doing to our flying students (Australian and overseas), to our foreign trade, to our own airmen and to our International reputation. We are working hard to attract to Australia people from other countries to offer them pilot training. In fact, we have some success in this regard. In my own electorate there are a number of student pilots training who are from Korea. But we must provide to the world confidence in our examination and our training system. We must be able to guarantee to the world that our safety regulator is as good as any in the world. Miss JACKIE KELLY (Lindsay) (11.20 a.m.)-The report on protocols II and IV to the Inhumane Weapons Convention is a very interesting report. It is something that I rise to speak on mainly from my experience in the legal field in our modem-day Australian Defence Force. The laws of war have been evolving since the Nuremberg trials. In 1925 there was the first attempt to make some sort of international treaty or agreement on conduct of armies during international conflict. It was quite interesting that at that stage it even led to different treatment of prisoners of war when the Germans captured English paws as compared to Russian paws, because they had a treaty with England and they did not with Russia. 7342 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 28 August 1997 Nuremberg put paid to all that, and came up with the concept of a crime against humanity. From the Second World War there were some very obvious examples, universally accepted today, about what is a crime against humanity, but we are still working towards a closer definition of acceptable conduct during conflict. The protocols that we are discussing here today in terms of the use of laser weapons and the use of antipersonnel landmines are two areas in this evolution of the law. We run a very professional Australian Defence Force. They have a number of standards. Right from recruit training, they are given numerous lectures and training and indoctrination in acceptable conduct for a professional modern-day military force. They are also involved in international conventions, courses and conferences, at which they spread ideas to other armies. Over the years of my involvement in this area, I have seen various nations-in our region, especially-adopting the laws of war. It has not only been their chiefs of staff: I have seen them gradually inculcating that right through to the lowest ranking serving members. This is what is so important in modern warfare: the sense of professionalism and what is acceptable and what is not. The international treaties we are discussing today go a long way towards setting up that humane standard for everyone to follow during times of conflict, when a lot of ordinary intercourse or everyday life is incredibly disrupted. An obvious example of that is antipersonnel landmines. They have attracted a lot of coverage since Vietnam, when they were most effectively deployed, and subsequent to that, when the cost on civilian life came to be counted. That human experience has led to the current major campaign for an international ban on antipersonnel landmines. They are not designed to kill people-merely to injure them; because a military force can be disabled much more effectively if members are injured rather than dead. The injured are assisted by their comrades, whereas the dead are simply buried. Antipersonnel mines have had a delaying effect in terms of restricting areas which armies must have personnel to defend. They could cover one flank with a minefield and set up their offensive operations on another flank. These days, in modern warfare with armoured personnel carriers and anti-mine tanks and vehicles, it is very easy for opposing military forces to breach minefields. These days they are not even a delaying factor. Armies can move at pretty well ordinary military speed across most minefields with the right equipment. That leaves the mines behind after the conflict has moved on for agricultural workers, for children looking for firewood, for women and children and civilians to suffer the awful consequences of nondetectable antipersonnel mines. Many things can be done to deploy mines. The military has come a long way in the evolution of mines, mainly looking at the security of their personnel. For instance, mines can deactivate or self-destruct after a certain time or have a time limit on them. There are all sorts of methods. Given the technology available today, you have to wonder at the strategic advantage of having mines at all. In 1997, they have very limited use, even as a delaying tactic at best and certainly not as a defensive military weapon. The Red Cross has led the major campaign against mines. Obviously, they are left behind, after most wars, to pick up the pieces of humanity-the terrible injuries to the children and the amputees. It does not matter whether there are 500 mines in a field or only one. They all have to be surveyed and cleared. Australia has an incredible record in its UN operations in terms of demining areas in Afghanistan, Angola, Cambodia, Laos and Mozambique. We have also had involvement in Pakistan and Namibia and in the Middle East conflicts. Thursday, 28 August 1997 MAIN COMMITIEE 7343 Our ADF's ability to demine areas has made a significant contribution to UN efforts in wartorn zones and in the re-establishment of law and order in those areas. It is a skill that we would wish our ADF personnel to retain. However, it is something that we want to take the lead on. The ministerial statement last year on this matter quite clearly led the world on this and made a great leap forward for Australia in finally proposing these protocols. The numbers of mines in the world today is something that really needs to be emphasised and considered. It would take something like 1,000 years to clear all the active landmines already in place. It will cost about $US33 billion to rid the world of all the mines that are there. For every 20 that are laid, only one is cleared. As many as five million new mines may be laid in anyone year. It can cost between $US200 and $US1,000 to clear each mine. It is a massive social problem left behind after conflict. Although conflict is the complete breakdown of law and order, the ultimate objective of any professional army is to return to law and order, to return the established systems where there is safety and security for all. The use of antipersonnel mines in an undetectable and indiscriminate fashion during conflict has a horrific aftermath and a cost to civilians, who, quite clearly, since 1945, have not been the target of any attack or military objective. Mines are incredibly cheap to make. They can be built in garages, fields or kitchens. They generally tend to be the preferred weapon of choice in underdeveloped countries. The time is well past for Australia to take a stand in leading the attitude to a professional deployment of military power. The statements by the minister to date have gone a fair way to doing that and Australia's ratification of these protocols heads that way, as well. The other protocol mentioned concerns laser weapons. As yet, we are still feeling our way in this murky field of law to come to some understanding and standards which will be considered humane. Man's arms race is certainly ahead of itself on this one. We currently use lasers to designate targets for guided bomb systems. What is the effect of those? What is the effect from that of now moving forward to developing the laser itself as the projectile rather than a bullet, with the terrible consequences of blindness or the aftermath on the civilian population in a conflict? This was clearly seen with the use of mustard gas in World War I. Loss of eyesight and the subsequent consequences to society in dealing with the costs of blindness and retraining and reskilling people who have lost such a substantial part of their independence have already been seen throughout history. We must move slowly towards finding acceptable standards and uses for this technology that comes up every day from our scientists and engineers, who are constantly pushing back the frontiers of science. It is something that I feel very strongly about. I think Australia should be leading world opinion. Without the modern armies doing so, we have little hope of underdeveloped countries taking the same professional attitude to the deployment of military power. That has an adverse consequence on our military personnel when they come up against an opponent who does not comply with the laws of war. That was clearly seen in the recent Gulf War in the Middle East. The Iraqi military forces had used chemical weapons against the Iranians in their previous eight-year war, but they failed to do so in the Gulf War. They respected the discipline of the forces that were there, in an acknowledgment that they would not use chemical weapons. A balance was achieved in terms of warfare that was conducted quite clearly within the bounds of the laws of war, the Geneva conventions, the subsequent protocols and all the other treaties that we continually develop in the international sphere in the hope of attaining some form of international 7344 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 28 August 1997 agreement on what is the definition of a crime against humanity. I commend the report to the House. discussion of the report that I was very proud to have played a part in compiling. The fifth report of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties is certainly worthy of debate here today and its discussion is a very important national as well as international matter. Restrictions on the use of blinding laser weapons and land mines: 5th report is the name of the report. The joint standing treaties committee will next week table its ninth report in less than a year. I have to say it was privilege enough for me to have been elected to this place to represent the good people of the electorate of Moreton. It was an unexpected honour to be appointed by the parliament to the joint standing treaties committee and to participate in a very important process, the deliberation and consideration of the international linkages that Australia has. Certainly, a criticism often offered to me in the lead-up to the last election was that there were just so many agreements that Australia had with other countries and other entities around the world and that there really was no accounting back to the parliament. It is a great credit to the Prime Minister( Mr Howard) to have embraced an agenda first put forward by Senator Rod Kemp of Victoria-now Assistant Treasurer-to have this treaties process. It is very important that the consideration of treaties and international agreements of all types is not just the domain of the executive or the foreign affairs club. We have been able to break through the obvious and natural barriers of the bureaucracy in the committee process to expose a number of very important issues to date. The committee's work range has included everything from tuna fishing through to the rights of the child, which is the current inquiry. This report before us is one that I was very pleased to be part of for a number of reasons. I will mention a couple of them. It helped me to keep faith, as a member in this place, with a lot of people who wrote to me prior to the election looking for some action on just this issue. People from Catholic Social Response, the International Red Cross, Amnesty International and others all have an interest, naturally enough, in the use of landmines. They are simply one of the most cowardly forms of weaponry used by armies around the world. I am very pleased to be part of a government whose Minister for Foreign Affairs( Mr Downer), on 15 April last year-in essentially one of the first acts of the new governmentdeplored the use of landmines and stated very clearly Australia's position. As the honourable member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly) just said, we have a vital leadership role in our region, particularly to show countries such as Cambodia-with not just its killing fields but also its maiming fields-that we do not believe the use of landmines is good enough. I join with the honourable member for Lindsay, and I am sure others in this place, in calling on the government to get even tougher on the use of landmines. They are simply horrendous weapons. They leave in their wake children, particularly, who, after conflicts, may wander into fields, into what would normally be productive areas, and trip over these things. They are not designed to kill; they are designed to maim. They were designed to maim sections of the opposing army because it paralyses an army. It is bad enough when a soldier is killed, but when a soldier is injured two other soldiers are then taken out to carry that injured soldier. There is at least a triplication effect with these sorts of weapons. So we now have in countries in our region children innocently tripping over landmines and losing limbs. The photos in this report provided by Dr William Maley are just too horrendous

speaker: Mr Hardgrave (Moreton) (11.34 A.m.)
theText: I am very pleased to participate in theThursday, 28 August 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 7345 to contemplate, with large rafts of skin being torn off innocent children. Landmines have to go. Landmines are quite easy to make. They are literally being made in people's kitchens and underneath people's homes. In fact, it is quite astonishing to note, and we received evidence to suggest this, that some of the very best electrical companies around the world have their components stuck inside some of these landmines. I am not about to advocate that we should be putting a ban on products that are also produced by these companies-because I suspect, in their defence, a lot of the materials used are simply cast off components that have been picked up by those who want to make these bombs and who do so, literally, on the kitchen table. They are everywhere. As the honourable member for Lindsay has alluded to, and this is contained within the report, antipersonnellandmines total 400 million since the Second World War. The US State Department has estimated that there are more than 85 million uncleared landmines scattered in 62 countries around the world, and five million new landmines are being laid each and every year, with a cost of up to $US 1,000 to clear each mine. There is evidence from the International Red Cross that for every 1andmine cleared 20 additional are laid. It would cost in the vicinity of $US33 billion to rid the world of this scourge. We are not about to get rid of landmines tomorrow. I certainly wished that I could have been part of a process that had got rid of landmines but I think the important part about this report is that it states very clearly the view of the parliament. I am glad to see the government is going down the same track. Landmines are dreadful devices and they should be taken out of the play, as far as the world is concerned. I think it is also important to note the evidence of Dr William Maley with regard to some of the ways that these landmines are quite deliberately being used. The last thing a retreating army does is to lay landmines in and around hospitals, schools and fields that can be used for food production. It is a quite deliberate and cowardly device used by a retreating army to inflict horrendous psychological and physical damage on the opposing side when they reclaim the land. As I said, I was proud to be part of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties in the compilation of this report. I am very pleased that we have discussed this here today and I urge the government to continue its efforts to rid the world of these mines. Also, in closing, I wish to register my praise for the role of the Australian defence forces, who quite rightly maintain a small stock of landmines here in this country in order to train and to maintain their expertise in order to continue their important role in ridding the world of these devices. Australian Defence Force personnel are amongst the best in clearing landmines, and God speed to their work. that this report of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties is being given time for debate in the Main Committee today. This was, of course, a very important inquiry by the treaties committee. The committee was required to respond to a proposal by the government to sign these particular protocols, but it was also a very heart-wrenching experience for the members of the committee. As the previous speaker mentioned, the committee was exposed to really horrific photographic evidence of the effects of landmines, and a couple of those photographs were reproduced in the committee's report.

speaker: Mr Truss (Wide Bay) (11.41 A.m.)
theText: Ijoin the previous speakers in expressing satisfaction7346 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 28 August 1997 In addition to that we had to deal with fairly complex issues. Whilst everyone has a horror of war and a horror of the tools of war, there is a recognition of the fact that our country cannot leave itself defenceless in the event of our nation being subjected to some kind of threat. So it is important to strike a balance between a desire to act humanely, even in times of war and national distress, and being able to adequately defend our country. It is, perhaps, a reflection of the fact that these issues were difficult that there was a minority report. I think that this is the only report of the treaties committee that included a minority report and I want to talk a little bit about the issues in that minority report in my contribution today. We have the benefit during this debate of having also at our disposal the government's response to the report. So we have the evidence of not only the six recommendations, but also the way in which the government has responded to these proposals. Whilst the government has not accepted all of the recommendations, I think the response has generally been reasonable. The first matter dealt with by the committee was protocol IV dealing with blinding laser weapons. It needs to be emphasised right at the beginning that blinding laser weapons are still in the developmental phase and there is no evidence that they have ever been used in conflict to date. In prohibiting a yet to be invented-yet to be fully developed-weapon, protocol IV is dealing with largely experimental or unexplored territory. But it is recognised that this is a major advance. It is obviously far better to ban a horrible weapon before it is used than to merely respond to international outrage after it has been used in conflict. So in that regard this protocol breaks new ground, and it is very pleasing to note that Australia will be amongst the first countries to assent to this protocol. One of the witnesses to the committee made the point that the protocol actually bans only the use and transfer of blinding laser weapons and not their actual production or development. So we could still see some degree of experimental work being done, although to no avail for those countries who have actually signed the protocol. The risk with this protocol-indeed, with all rules of war-is that the despotic regimes who are perhaps less concerned about humanitarian issues, those who might be most likely to use these kinds of weapons if they could gain access to them, are the ones that will not sign the protocol. So countries that have a more responsible attitude are naturally concerned about the exposure of their troops or their people in wartime to a weapon that they have voluntarily chosen not to use. So, in a sense, many countries are adopting something of a defensive mechanism by saying that they are prepared to work on the technology but will not actually use it when the time comes. There is also no absolute ban under protocol IV on the use of lasers in wartime, merely on the use of blinding laser weapons. There has already been use of lasers in guidance systems, and I think there is likely to be a lot more development in that regard. I am not sure that is necessarily inhumane. Lasers provide considerable enhancement to the accuracy of weapons, and that is likely to make them better able to target a military objective rather than indiscriminately slaughtering humans. I think there is likely to be substantial further development of laser guidance systems, and that will probably be an advancement rather than a disadvantage. Australia has indicated that it will be moving to sign this protocol and to commit our country to its obligations. Thursday, 28 August 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 7347 The other area that has been covered has been the question of antipersonnellandmines. This has been a matter of considerable distress, widespreadA division having been called in the House of RepresentativesSitting suspended from 11.46 a.m. to 11.58 a.m. of landmines and the committee's report on amended protocol II, which deals with mines, booby traps and other devices. It again needs to be pointed out that this protocol does not actually talk about banning these weapons but merely talks about prohibiting or restricting the use of particular mines. The Australian government has responded in a positive way in relation to this protocol. Antipersonnel landmines contained in the Australian defence stockpile basically comply with the restrictions required under the revised protocol II, although I understand that the M14 mines would need minor modification if they were ever to be used in the future. Affairs( Mr Downer) announced a unilateral suspension by Australia of the operational use of antipersonnellandmines by the Australian Defence Force and that the measure would take effect immediately. It is important to note that Australia does not actually produce or export landmines itself. The government indicated that the suspension would, for all intents and purposes, be permanent. It would be subject to review only in the case of a substantial deterioration in our strategic situation. The Australian government is retaining a national antipersonnel landmine stockpile to provide a defensive capability in the event of substantial deterioration in Australia's strategic circumstances, The committee, as I mentioned earlier, was divided on the issue of the extent of Australia's response on antipersonnel landmines. The majority of the committee recommended that Australia destroy its stockpile of antipersonnel landmines, except for a small number to be retained for training purposes to ensure that the Australian Defence Force retains its skill. In other words, the committee was recommending unilateral action by Australia to destroy its stockpile, an action which I understand Canada has already taken. It would certainly provide a very strong lead to the world that Australia regarded the use of these sorts of weapons as unacceptable. There was, however, a significant minority report which recommended that Australia should declare its willingness to destroy its landmines, except for training stock. It should only destroy the rest of its landmines once a substantial number of significant nations in our region have committed themselves to this course according to an agreed international timetable. The question arose as to whether Australia should undertake the symbolic act of destroying its landmines to demonstrate to the world that these weapons were regarded as unacceptable, or whether our assurance not to use them and not to review that assurance unless we were subject to significant threat is a more reasonable response. I have to say that, on balance, I come down on the side of the government's position. I do so because Australia is a vast country. It is a nation that is not threatened at the present time. Frankly, I doubt that our country will be threatened in the future. I certainly hope that that is the case. We need to do all that we can as a nation diplomatically to ensure that we retain a cordial relationship with our neighbours. But there is a possibility that our situation could deteriorate. Any prudent country will always plan also for the circumstances when it must

speaker: On 15 April 1996, The Minister For Defence ( Mr Mclachlan) And The Minister For Foreign
theText: 7348 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 28 August 1997 defend itself. To unilaterally disarm when no-one else in our neighbourhood would be taking such action would be regarded by many as foolhardy. We also need to recognise that our nation has a very large coastline that is almost impossible to defend with traditional armaments, no matter how powerful our defence forces might be. Of course, we have the benefit of wonderful new technology, early radar defence systems and the like. But it is conceivable that, if an invasion was threatened, with the availability of the sorts of weapons that we know exist at this time, Australia may need to use antipersonnel landrnines to defend itself from a military invasion. Such weapons should only be used in those sorts of circumstances. There are a wide range of other rules in protocol II, and in the various rules of war, about the way in which landmines should be used. Sadly, it has been an ignorance of those laws which has been a part of the destruction and damage and injury to people in Asia and other parts of the world. The existing protocols have not worked in many of those countries. Sadly, for the same reasons as I referred to at the beginning of my remarks, there is a risk that the new protocol rules may not work in those countries as well. The government has made it clear that it regards the use of these weapons as unacceptable, and that Australia itself will not use landmines. The government has also indicated its willingness to look at the second part of the committee's recommendation, which was that Australia should prepare for consideration at the December 1997 meeting in Canada a proposal for the creation of an agreed international timetable for the destruction of antipersonnel landmines of all nations. This takes up the point of the minority report. Australia stands ready to destroy its own landmines, but would like to act in concert with other nations so that our whole region would be rid of these appallingly destructive weapons. As was mentioned earlier by the member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly) in particular, this is a weapon that is designed as much to harm innocent civilians as it is to stem the flow or advance of an army. Such a deployment of landmines is a clear abuse of a whole range of Geneva conventions, but those conventions have not prevented it from happening. They have not prevented the appalling injuries that were referred to earlier. What we do need is a strong diplomatic offensive to seek an agreement by all of the countries of our region-indeed, hopefully all of the countries in the world-to move to eliminate antipersonnel landmines. Australia has indicated that it is prepared to act cooperatively with other countries in that regard. I commend to the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Foreign Affairs the proposal that they should pursue this objective strongly when the meeting occurs in Canada later this year. Mr Deputy Speaker, these two protocols have the potential to help make the world a safer place, to free the world of the threat of some of the most potentially and actually horrific weapons that are used from time to time in war. Australia has an honourable record in defence of our country and in wartime. We have been involved in conflicts, however, where the conventions have frequently been ignored. I hope that there will be international effort to ensure that our world is made safer by the elimination of these sorts of weapons. Debate (on motion by Mr Griffin) adjourned. Thursday, 28 August 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 7349 National Crime Authority Committee Report Debate resumed from 27 August, on motion by Mr Reith: That the House take note of the report. Committee on the National Crime Authority's report on organised criminal paedophile activity, which has followed the publication of the report in November 1995, is a timely one. It comes at the same time that the Wood royal commission has released the final report into its inquiries into paedophile activity and other aspects relating to the corruption in the New South Wales police force. I was a sponsor of this particular inquiry, and visited the National Criminal Intelligence Service in the United Kingdom last year. I might point out to those who may not be aware that this is now considered to be one of the authorities for material related to research into organised or other paedophile activity. I might also point out that the recommendations of that particular report coincide neatly with the findings of the Wood royal commission with relation to the extent of organised criminal paedophile activity, and also some other aspects. I must say this, though: one of the things I would strongly object to in relation to the Wood royal commission's findings is the proposal to reduce the age of consent for homosexual behaviour to 16 years. I would strongly oppose that for a variety of reasons, which I might touch on later if I have time. The most important thing is to look at the circumstances surrounding the release of both the report and the response by the federal government. The report came at a time when there was considerable debate and speculation in the community about the extent to which organised criminal paedophile activity was operating in the community. At the same time we were perhaps 10 months down the track from the introduction of legislation that made it an offence to participate in child sex tourism-some groundbreaking legislation. In fairness to the previous Labor government, it was initiated by the Labor government, under Minister Kerr at the time, and has proved not to be a blinding success, but at least it has been available as part of the array of weapons against the sort of behaviour that most people would find totally reprehensible. Australians unfortunately were beginning to get the reputation for being some of the worse offenders in the cases where, because of our proximity to some of these areas of attraction, tours were being organised and people were visiting these particular areas solely for the purpose of accessing juveniles for sexual purposes. When we made these recommendations, there were some concerns about the extent to which the Australian law enforcement authorities were getting cooperation from their counterparts overseas, in particular in Thailand. One of the recommendations was to look at beefing up the relationship, the liaison, between the Thai police and the Australian Federal Police. At the time, the Thai police had something in the region of 150,000 police officers but only four were allocated as liaison officers to the Australian Federal Police. Considering the amount of drug trafficking investigation and detection which was taking place, this tended to give the impression that they viewed the child sex tourism area with a very low priority indeed. In fact, there were a number of allegations-to us and elsewhere during the debate that gave rise to the child sex tourism legislation in the first place-that corrupt officials, corruption within the
