speaker: Mr Filing (Moore) (12.08 P.m.)
theText: The government response to the Joint Statutory7350 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 28 August 1997 criminal system within Thailand, impeded the investigative work of people trying to get to the bottom of, or trying to investigate, particular cases. We are now halfway through the term of the Howard government, a government elected to strengthen the role of the family in the community. Paedophile activity is very closely related to this. For instance, the statistics from the Wood royal commission show that 46 per cent of proven victims are assaulted by family members. Fifty-four per cent of proven victims are assaulted by a non-family member; of those, 44 per cent are assaulted by an adult known to the family. In this case, one can clearly see that there is a very strong need, a very serious need, to strengthen, not weaken, the opportunity for the family unit to be able to be an influence against paedophile behaviour. It is also a fact, not refuted, that many assaults are undertaken in the case of de facto relationships by a de facto stepfather on a stepdaughter. This is another area of concern. But what concerns me most is the fact that, notwithstanding the commitment of the Howard government to beefing up the family unit as the principal source of comfort, care, love and education in our community, there are aspects of government policy that are undermining and weakening substantially the opportunity for families to be able to combat the influence of paedophile behaviour. I can give you a few examples from my own electorate, ones that have occurred very recently. Amongst some more recent ones was a case where two 14-year-old girls ran away from home. They met up with some youths in town, who then persuaded them to come and live at their place, which was like an open house, effectively under the control of a woman who was seeing a number of men. These girls moved there unbeknownst to their parents. They were believed to be participating in drug taking, in sexual activity on the premises. One of them ended up getting assaulted, their health suffered and their condition and welfare were seriously under question. The interesting thing was that, notwithstanding the fact that their father reported the girls missing immediately, the police could not tell the father where these gids were. The police would not act to bring these girls back home. Under the circumstances, I would have considered that to be entirely reprehensible. At the same time, the state department-that is, the family and community services department of the Western Australia government, another coalition government, I might add, in its second term of government-also failed to act, under the act which it has responsibility for administering. So we have the situation where the father appeared on the Howard Sattler program-one of Perth's popular radio talk back shows-and quizzed the Premier one month after the girls had actually disappeared. The Premier said that he would get the minister to act immediately on this. Within the period that the Premier was informed and the matter came back to my attention, one of the girls had been assaulted so badly that she had to have stitches around her eye. We understand that there were other men coming into the household and sexual activity had taken place with these girls, who were 14-year-old twins. In fact, when one went to a doctor's surgery, she collapsed from malnutrition in the doctor's surgery. Interestingly enough, when the woman that was acting in loco parentis, so to speak, for these girls went to the Department of Social Security in her local area-a federal department-she was able to get family allowance payments for the girls. Then the Department of Social Security wrote to the parents and told them they had to repay the money they had received as family allowance payments. Eventually, after contacting the minister, we got an apology Thursday, 28 August 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 7351 from the minister's office for what is, in my view, entirely reprehensible behaviour by the Department of Social Security. It gives an indication of just how serious the problem is. If a parent is conscious of their child being under threat or if the child leaves home before they are of the age of sexual consent, then they have little to no influence over that child's welfare-to such an extent that a government department would be very reluctant to retum that child to the home, even if they were of the opinion that that particular child was engaging in under-age sexual activity. Where we have the government yesterday saying that it wanted to do something about this terrible problem of paedophile activity-and it is a terrible problem-we have the situation where, within its own departments, it is in fact encouraging the very behaviour through its own lack of support for the role of the parents. The other problem is: what does the government do under the circumstances? The government has responded to a range of recommendations made by our committee and in most cases they have agreed to them. In particular, of course, the most important of those, as far as the Commonwealth government is concerned, is in the circulation of information relating to the activities of paedophiles. It is quite clear that paedophiles, by their nature, gravitate to their place of opportunity-to the place where they can access their prey. In many instances, they move from place to place. You would be perhaps totally unfamiliar with the fact that across the road from your children lived somebody who may have been convicted for sexually assaulting children-who may have served a prison sentence and come back to live in the community. We have seen in the United States a considerable social movement, a popular movement, to have legislation enacted by President Clinton to in fact make it mandatory for local authorities to inform the local community in the case where somebody with that sort of criminal background moves into the community. We have seen instances where people of that particular nature have moved back in and recommitted offences. People who were living across the road, or in that community, did not know because the authorities would not tell them. We have this similar problem here in Australia, where, for instance, a parent, in anguish, goes to a government department, state or federal, asking for help to get their daughter or son away from a situation in which they are in sexual activity with people who are over the age of consent or adults-in other words paedophile activity. They cannot get any help, notwithstanding the fact that there is legislation there to actually guide them or to provide that power. There is a policy in the family and children's services department in Western Australia not to enforce it-not to return the child to their home. In fact, the policy is to take the view of the child if the child wilfully wants to engage in this activity. One of the reasons why I strongly oppose the reduction of the age of consent for homosexual behaviour is that it is a well-known fact that adult homosexual males prey on juvenile males in a way that contributes to the behaviour. In fact, many of them are more prosperous or they spend lots of money and do things to try and smother the person or to make the person feel comfortable or happy in their company and then use that to break down any perhaps resistance or natural concerns they might have about behaviour. It is quite clear, particularly when you look at some of the evidence that has arisen as a result of the New South Wales royal commission, that in fact this is still going on today to a wide extent. 7352 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 28 August 1997 I personally would like to congratulate two people who have done a good job in relation to their parliamentary duties in New South Wales. They are on the other side of the fence politically from me, but they are people who have taken a stand on it and have actually done something. I think that members of parliament have a duty to act where they feel that it is in the interests of the community to act. I refer to Franca Arena and Deirdre Grusovin, who were reviled in the media at one stage and then praised at another. They took it upon themselves to use their parliamentary privilege, something that is a privilege to all of us, to act on behalf of their constituents. That is what it is for. In both cases, in my view, they have been shown to have made a contribution. It is quite clear that, in the absence of action and in the absence of people taking it upon themselves to act, the problem has gotten out of hand in New South Wales and has given rise to this royal commission there. I would like also to make an observation in relation to the problem that we touched upon in our particular report relating to Cambodia. World Vision gave evidence to us in Melbourne that there was the very serious problem of paedophiles accessing World Vision child sponsorship programs, becoming a sponsor and then going to the country where the child lived and accessing that child for sexual purposes, knowing full well that in many instances, both culturally and because of their particular circumstance of poverty, the parents may well not resist the overtures made by that particular paedophile activist. I have also been very disappointed over the period of time since the allegations were first raised about the role of Australia's mission in Cambodia in relation to paedophile activity because it is now clear that under the circumstances there was substantial negligence in relation to that activity in Cambodia, activity that the World Vision organisation brought to the attention of the committee at an early stage during our inquiry. I might also say that, unfortunately, the government says that it agrees that it needs to cooperate with countries like Cambodia. It said: ... the Government has now removed the need to negotiate treaties in all but the most exceptional circumstances. While the Government is not prepared to pursue treaties with Cambodia and other South East Asian countries, it considers that the changes it has made to the scheme of the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987 will remove significant impediments to, and thus facilitate greater cooperation with, countries in our region in the investigation and prosecution of child sex offences. It did say in its response that it felt that the liaison efforts of the AFP would assist. Unfortunately, in the case of Cambodia, when the allegations were made in the case of a member of Australia's diplomatic mission, the AFP was forced to do an inquiry here in Australia, offshore. The AFP did not even send personnel to Cambodia, and it did not give rise to a prosecution for some time down the track. I know that the Australian Federal Police Association was particularly disappointed with the response made by the government at the time and by the fact that there was not an onshore investigation in the country where the offences were alleged to have taken place. In conclusion, I want to make the following point. Nothing that can be done by the federal government in relation to paedophile activity will succeed unless we give the family unit the opportunity, the support, to be able to combat the problem in the first place. I might say also that it is highly disappointing that some of the government's own departments, particularly the Department of Social Security, may well be contributing inadvertently to the problem in the first place. It is a pity that events in the Western Australian Liberal Party prior to the last election led to his being a loss to our party because I know on these sorts of issues that he has very strong views, and views with which I agree very strongly. It is interesting that this debate is occurring here today. I would have thought that there would be a list of speakers 25 or 30 long taking the opportunity to speak about this matter here in the Main Committee, given the current climate. I suppose it emphasises the importance of this committee to members. There are other matters on the agenda here today that are equally important in a lot of respects. The Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs report on youth suicide is also on the agenda. There are a limited number of speakers. In many respects this debate should be going on in the House of Representatives chamber itself because of the fact that it is such an important issue. I am not necessarily being critical of my colleagues, but somehow the processes and the opportunity is not getting through to people, and on this particular issue of paedophilia I would have thought there would have been a lot more speakers. The member for Moore has a great deal of credibility in respect of what he has had to say this morning. For a start, he was on the committee during its inquiry and he is the only member of the committee who is still on the Joint Statutory Committee on the National Crime Authority, the committee which I currently chair. He was on that committee at the time that it brought down this excellent report, but more than that, as I understand it, he actually drove the committee on this report. It was his knowledge of this subject, as a former policeman, that drove this report. It is really quite amazing that here we have a report that was brought down in this parliament on November 1995 on a subject that this day is on the lips of every Australian. In 1995 I think most Australians would not have been able to spell 'paedophile', let alone know what it was all about. Yet today we have this debate not only following the Wood royal commission but within a couple of weeks of the report of the Children's Commission of Queensland to the Queensland government, entitled Paedophilia in Queensland. I do not want to overdo it, but let me tell the parliament that the member for Moore has made a very significant and relevant speech here today and he deserves a great deal of credit for the committee's work on this subject. We are dealing now with the government's response to the report. I note that the government has accepted every recommendation made by the committee in its report, but this is only the beginning of a role for the Commonwealth on this subject, because of its importance-which, as I said, has been underlined by events in the last few days. I do not think anyone would suggest that paedophilia is new, that it is something that has just started to happen. The evidence is that it has been going on for a very long time, but it has been one of those subjects that people have not wanted to talk about. It is not a very nice subject to talk about and I suppose those of us who have had some responsibilities and opportunities to talk about it have probably abrogated those responsibilities by not being prepared to do that. We now understand, as a result of events in recent days, the extent of this problem and, probably worse even than the extent of it, the actual nature of it, which Justice Wood spelt out not only in his report but in subsequent interviews. speaker: Mr Bradford (Mcpherson) 02.23 P.m.)
theText: I congratulate the member for Moore( Mr7354 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 28 August 1997 graphically enough some of the horrific and horrible evidence with which he had been presented on this particular activity. But the Queensland Children's Commission report makes the point, in relation to Queensland, that: The existence of a hard-core group of some 300 active paedophiles in the State is cause for a considerable concern. That has to be an understatement. The report goes on: When it is recalled that a single paedophile may sexually abuse on average 150 victims, an estimated 45,000 Queensland children consequently are destined to carry the scars of sexual abuse by this 300. To these figures of course must be added many thousands of Queensland men and women who, during their adulthood, are now also bearing the emotional and physical scars of sexual abuse as children. Studies relied upon by the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence (ABCI) provide a basis for assessing the statistical magnitude of paedophile activity in the State. These studies suggest that one in four girls and one in eleven boys are sexually abused by the time they reach the age of 18 years. Out of Queensland's population of persons aged 0-17 years, some 150,000 will consequently carry the emotional and physical scars of sexual abuse throughout their adult lives. This number will augment the number of existing adults who in their childhoods were also subjected to sexual abuse. That number of persons now over 18 years of age in Queensland is of the order of 420,000. When it is recalled that 70% of persons in psychiatric units of some of our hospitals are known to have been sexually abused as children, we can begin to see the true dimensions of the societal scourge which paedophilia constitutes. That report came out on 5 August, just a couple of weeks before Justice Wood brought down his report into the New South Wales situation, which is equally as bad, maybe even worse. So we have a problem that is not only in Queensland, is not only in New South Wales, but, by any estimate, is an Australia-wide one of enormous proportions. I want to say that the member for Moore is absolutely right when he puts this in the context of family and family breakdown. I do not know whether there has been any research done about this. Paedophilia has probably been going on for a long time. Certainly, family breakdown in society has contributed to the extent of paedophilia. It is interesting to talk about abuse within the family. There is a headline in my local paper today 'Fathers top list for child abuse'. 'The most common child molesters are fathers and stepfath6rs', it says. I would contend-but I do not have the statistics to back it here-that most of that abuse is being inflicted by stepfathers or by a parent in a de facto relationship. That is my contention. Let me base that on this fact: as far as I can see the abuse of a child by a natural father is at the absolute horrific end of the scale. We are not downplaying other parts of this scale of abuse, which are equally concerning. My guess would be that abuse of a daughter by a natural father would not be a frequent occurrence. Therefore, when we start to see headlines like 'Fathers top list for child abuse', I believe the real emphasis is probably going to be on stepfathers and parents in de facto relationships. One of the problems that the member for Moore touched on is that this sort of debate provides fertile ground for the anti-family element in our society to get in and say that children are all abused in family relationships and, therefore, families are bad and the sooner the children are taken over by someone outside the family, where they will not get abused, the better. That is what really worries me about where this debate may ultimately go. WhatI am sure of-and I have given a lot of thought to this over the years-is that we have in our society a very great problem with the breakdown of family. It leads to all sorts of other Thursday, 28 August 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 7355 problems. Children are hurt by divorce in many ways. Whilst for a while there was trendy evidence coming out to tell us that children are better off if their parents get divorced, the latest evidence and the most persuasive evidence is that that is not the case, and that children suffer from divorced parents for a very long time in their lives. Now we are seeing very strong evidence that when divorces occur and we have these blended families, and blended families on blended families, the capacity for paedophilia-abuse of young children-is magnified because of that many times. It gets back in my view, as the member for Moore made very clear, to a concern about the state of families in our nation. Whilst he was mildly critical of the performance of the government of which I am a member, I would defend the government. I think this government was elected with a very strong mandate to support families. I believe that we delivered on that commitment and we are further in the process of delivering on that commitment. I am coming very much from a concern as a pro-family person in this parliament. Aspects of our policies have not moved quickly enough, but this issue may well galvanise us into further action. The question which has been raised, and it was raised in the Queensland commissioner's report, is what the national response ought to be. The focus therefore comes back almost the full circle on the National Crime Authority and what role, if any, it ought to have in this. In fact, the Queensland commissioner says: Within the past decade a number of agencies established to focus on crime and its link to corruption of public officials in particular has addressed their role in combating paedophilia. In Queensland, this has involved the CJC and, at a national level, the NCA. In examining their jurisdictions for paedophilia, both agencies seem to have taken as a starting point, their mandate in relation to organised crime. They then proceeded to address the question as to whether the available evidence regarding paedophilia suggests an organised activity. As a result of certain specific characteristics of organised activity these agencies have concluded that paedophile activity does not qualify as an organised activity in the terms of reference specified by them. From the standpoint of the relevant agency such an approach may be justified but, from the wider perspective of community interest and welfare, it does not seem very helpful and it constitutes something of an academic exercise. I tend to agree with the Children's Commissioner there. The issue of whether there is a role for the NCA in this has exercised my mind. The NCA has completed a strategic assessment of paedophile activity in Australia and the Attorney General( Mr Williams) currently has that on his desk. My committee has asked to be briefed on the outcome of that assessment. We have asked for the assessment but there will be some very sensitive areas and we may not get the actual assessment. But, of course, we are looking forward to having a briefing on it. I think we can then look closely at whether there are some definitional problems in terms of whether it is organised criminal activity for the purposes of whether the NCA ought to be involved, and we may well proceed to address those particular issues. The NCA has proved its effectiveness because it can cross jurisdictional boundaries, and so on, in combating a lot of aspects of organised crime. I believe it would be counterproductive to get bogged down in the question of whether paedophile activity is organised crime. The NCA committee, under my chairmanship, will continue to address the issue. The report that the committee did in 1995, driven largely, as I said earlier, by the member for Moore, does 7356 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 28 August 1997 I think totally vindicate the concerns he had and his committee had then. Here it is, as I say, two years down the track and suddenly we have on our hands a recognition that we have here a very serious national problem. As a result of all of those considerations, the NCA committee will continue to focus on the issue. We look forward to seeing the outcome of the strategic assessment. I understand that it largely confirms the findings of this report and indeed confirms Justice Wood's findings which indicated that paedophilia, whilst it was a great concern, was not a nationally organised activity: it was occurring on a local level, within the context of family relations, and it existed in fairly close networks. But, in my view, that should not be, as the Children's Commissioner in Queensland says, the ultimate determiner of whether we address it on a national issue. The government responded a little further in the parliament yesterday in response to a question about the Wood commission. I would like, if I had time, to deal a little further with the suggestion that there be a national council for the prevention of child abuse. Time will beat me on that but I am pleased that this has been listed for discussion here in the Main Committee today. (Time expired) Debate (on motion by Mr Griffin) adjourned. Industry, Science and Technology Committee Report Debate resumed from 27 August, on motion by Mr Reid: That the House take note of the report. Committee this afternoon on this particular report of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. I think most members of this House would know that I have always been a great supporter of the role that parliamentary committees can play in advancing ideas to government. In this particular case, I think this is not only a timely report but also one which this government needs to respond to quickly. Again, I put on public record that the Australian Labor Party will give swift passage through both the House of Representatives and the Senate to any of the recommendations requiring legislation arising out of the committee's report. I have said that publiCly. I have put that on the record in a number of different forums around this country in the last several months as we have talked to people in small business but I think it is the first opportunity that I have had to record it here in the parliament. I think it is important that that be said. I do not think anybody who has participated in discussions with small businesses, particularly small businesses and franchisees in shopping centres, could be left untouched by some of the stories that these people tell about the complete and disproportionate amount of market power working against the interests of small business. I have travelled around in my capacity as the shadow minister for small business in the last two months-in the break-and spoken to people in shopping centres in Rockhampton, Wollongong, Melbourne, Newcastle and the Gold Coast. The stories I was told were mirror images of the stories which colleagues who sat on this committee heard in evidence which they received. They were the stories of small business people, micro businesses, and mums and dads operations: in Australia some 50 per cent of businesses are operations run by one or two people, often family members, that do not employ anybody else.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Martin (Cunningham) (12.39 P.m.)
theText: It is a great pleasure to speak in the MainThursday, 28 August 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 7357 They told stories about the way in which market power was being used by shopping centre management and by owners of shopping centres to disadvantage them, and stories about being forced to relocate within shopping centres to areas where less passing traffic was going to mean a slashing of profitability for that small business and, in many cases, was going to cause it to go to the wall. They told stories about ways in which new tenancy agreements were struck and the way in which the small business person was disadvantaged in those negotiations with a virtual 'take it or leave it, and if you do not like it then you are out the door' type of arrangement. When you talk to franchisees of the common franchises that we see in shopping centres about some of the master franchisors they tell stories about the way some of those franchisors-not all of them, but some of them-deal with people. They tell stories about the up-front fees and the increases in outgoings which small businesses in shopping centres have to put up with. In one shopping centre I went to in Melbourne, the total cost of outgoings-the moneys that shopping centre tenants pay for things like joint advertising, cleaning, security and so on-was $600,000 in one year. The next year that was put up to $1.2 million. There was no consultation with the tenants. The centre management simply said, 'Here's your new bill and you are going to have to learn to live with it. Of course, you will be levied an increased fee for the privilege of having your premises cleaned, guarded and advertised in joint publications.' These are the sorts of issues which are out there in the ether. These are the sorts of problems facing small business. Much has been said about small business in this country over the last 12 to 18 months and perhaps longer. There are two things I want to say. Firstly, we on our side of the parliament would be the first to concede that when in government we probably did not move as quickly as we should have to protect small businesses from unconscionable conduct, predatory pricing and some of the other issues which have been outlined in this particular committee report. I accept that, and we are moving to try to redress that-albeit, unfortunately, from opposition. Secondly, I think it is fair to say that in the election in March last year there was a clear expectation from small businesses that if they voted to put the coalition into government they would have friends in court and the coalition would move to support small business. Regrettably, they are telling me that that is not happening. They are telling me that some of the things the Treasurer ( Mr Costello) or the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business( Mr Reith) are talking about at the moment, like capital gains tax, rollover provisions for retirement, unfair dismissal provisions and so on, whilst they are important to some small businesses, are not the key issues. What small businesses want is a return to profitability. What they want is business confidence. What they want is more people coming through the front door. But they also want protection. They want protection from unconscionable trade practice. They want protection from some of the activities that certain shopping centre managers embrace as part of their running of shopping centres. In fact, what small businesses are saying is that they want to find a balance. They want to redress the imbalance that presently exists between the small shops and the people that own the shopping centres and manage the shopping centres. They want to make sure that that balance is redressed, with equality in terms of negotiating power at least. This report makes specific recommendations about that. As I have said, this report goes to issues like franchising and retail tenancy legislation. And, importantly, it says that in both of 7358 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 28 August 1997 those instances, we should have legislation through changes to the Trade Practices Act underpinning codes of conduct. We could not agree more. Giving small businesses the opportunity to take on landlords who are unscrupulous, in a fair, reasonable and equal arrangement, is critical to the improvement of small business and its operation. I think that it needs to be said, also, that access to justice and the cost of access to justice are disproportionate-and examples are given in this particular report. It is very easy for the Woolworths and the other major shopping centre operators in this country to throw a ton of money and a truckload of lawyers at a small business person and bankrupt that person, causing marriage breakdowns and all sorts of difficulties for those people, and not think anything of it. On the other hand, if there were access to justice through tenancy tribunals, an equalisation of that power relationship which presently is so unequal would occur. Quite obviously then small business would feel much better off and would, in fact, be much better off. They are the recommendations contained in this report. Much has been said over the past several months about small business. In fact, it cost the former minister for small business, the member for Forrest( Mr Prosser), his position in this government, and we have a new minister now. This minister has said that he is going around talking to people. We all know that the government's response to this report was due last Tuesday. We have said to the minister that if he wants another couple of weeks because he is only new to the job, that is fine. He said that he wanted to talk to people to get an overview of what was going on. But while he is doing all that, of course, his bureaucracy is out there drafting the response that the government will bring down to this report. I know that there are members of the government parties-those members, particularly, who were part of the committee inquirythat will be doing their utmost to ensure that their government upholds every recommendation to the last word to ensure that small businesses do get a fair go. As I said, on 2 March last year there was an overwhelming depth of support for this government by small business. They expected to get something. They expected to see opportunities for small business to be improved and, as a consequence of this report now being released-it being known to so many in the small business community-they can only hope that the government will be true to its word. Not unexpectedly, the other side of the equation-best described, I guess, as the landlordsis fighting back. The landlords have asked Access Economics to produce a contrary view to the parliamentary committee report. This contrary review was put out a couple of weeks ago and it was called Tipping the balance. We all know in which direction that balance was proposed to be tipped when this analysis was done by Access Economics and came out on behalf of the Property Council of Australia. It was tipping it back towards the landlords. Quite frankly, the criticism that this document levels at a parliamentary committee-almost claiming that a parliamentary committee of the House of Representatives was unprofessional in its approach to an issue-is laughable. I know that someone like you, Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, who is as committed as I am to the way in which this parliament is seen as being so important to the nation's future and, to the fact that our committee system can make, and has made in the past, a tremendous contribution to changing government laws, would be just as offended as I am by some of the comments that are contained in here. Thursday, 28 August 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 7359 This creates an enormous problem for my good friend the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. On one hand, he has a parliamentary committee and his own colleagues saying unanimously that small business has got to be looked after. They are saying, 'Look after the small business community that voted for us. They deserve an equal chance.' On tre other hand, you have got a report from the Property Council of Australia which says, 'Don't worry about them; most of them are whingers anyway. Free competition is what it is all about. After all, Minister, the Property Council of Australia translates as landlords, and that translates as plenty of good donations around election time.' That is the balance that this minister is going to have to address. Much has been suggested about issues arising in this committee report. I am pleased to say that a number of media commentators have picked up on it and have reproduced some of the horrendous stories that were contained within it. But at the end of the day, it is simple for this government. They have a unanimous government report. They have the support of the opposition-and the Democrats, I might say-for enacting the legislative changes recommended in here and the other issues which are required and that will help small business. There is a win-win situation. This is one of the truly great moments in Australian politics, where all sides of the political fence are quite prepared to say to the small business community, 'We will help you. Here is the document that recommends how that will be done and here is the legislation going to pass through both houses of parliament with the support of every major political party.' I think that it is probably a bit of a rarity in this place to get everybody agreeing with each other. On the committee, I know my good friend the member for Scullin( Mr Jenkins), who was a very active member in this and played a very real role, and also my colleague the former minister for small business and the member for Rankin( Mr Beddall), had a lot of time and effort which they were prepared to expend with government members in arriving at that joint position on fair trading. If one quote illustrates the sorts of problems that small businesses have encountered as a result of this inequality in market power, it is the one that appears on page 4 of this report. I would like to have it read into Hansard. It is from an unspecified retailer because quite clearly she did not want to be identified. It reads: I once had a thriving business in an industry few could match my enthusiasm for ... [What the retail leases tribunal could not consider is the devastating effect the past five traumatic years have had on me and my family which not even our once rock solid 27 year marriage could survive. We were once confident, positive thinking go-getters but now we're broke and dispirited relics of our former selves with several stress related health problems, not the least being acute depression, insomnia, nervous tension and obesity. I went through premature menopause and my once cheerful, workaholic, loving partner is now an angry, aggressive alcoholic. Our children suffer too, helplessly watching both their parents fall to pieces before their eyes and their quality of life diminish. At 50 years of age, we've been left with a massive business debt, which we have insufficient earning power to repay, and ... we now face the real prospect of being homeless as well. The chains have been allowed to gobble us up and the landlord is allowed to trample us down. Our pleas to politicians fallon deaf ears and the legal system treats us with contempt. The end result is the tragedies exposed almost daily in the national news. Why must it be so? We too are entitled to our place in the sun. [The Fair Trading inquiry] has within its power to recommend that justice is done and if I believed in God anymore, I'd pray that you will ensure it is. 7360 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 28 August 1997 That is from the heart of a retailer who has suffered grievously because of past policies of all governments. Here, with this report, is an opportunity to redress those sorts of problems. The Labor Party, for its part, will help in that process. I have travelled extensively. I have spoken at retail rallies involving 500 people in Newcastle, 100 on the Gold Coast and 1,000 in Melbourne. They have told me what they want. Yet the minister for workplace relations came into this parliament yesterday and said what people want is capital gains tax rollover relief so they can pocket $500,000 on retirement. The only small businesses that could do that would be people that owned a McDonald's franchise or something similar, not the bulk of small businesses in this country. Respond to this committee inquiry report and justice will be done. (Time expired) committee that the children in the public galleries are from the Nambucca Heads Christian Community School, the jewel of the electorate of Cowper. Finding a balance: towards fair trading in Australia, a report which has been brought down by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. I also welcome the contribution made by the member for Cunningham ( Mr Martin), who has just left the room. WhilstI recognise and acknowledge his helpful gesture in putting into place the recommendations that have now been handed down in this report, I am a bit at a loss as to why he and his government had not done just as much in their previous years of being in government. It is rather a bit too late. I must say that, whilst I welcome his gesture of helping, it does seem to be a little bit hypocritical to change his mind so quickly in such a short time. Like the member who spoke before me, during my past 13 years of campaigning I too travelled very widely throughout my electorate. During that time. I became extremely aware of the fact that small business was very, very adversely affected in a number of areas, particularly in matters concerning franchising, retail tenancy and justice. There is no doubt that some small businesses were getting the rough end of the stick. In my discussions with those business owners I could sense the frustrations that they were experiencing as a result of what I would often consider to be very U):1scrupulous business practices. They were forced to work under conditions which were, to say the least, very exploitative in several instances. There is no doubt that as a committee we heard many stories of anger, disillusionment and complete despondency from small business people due to the treatment they received from big business operators. I believe that small business should be given the opportunity not only to survive but also to prosper, and to be free from the types of predatory practices and standover tactics that they have experienced from these people in the past. I am very proud to have been involved in such a concerted attempt to provide a fair and equitable report. One of the members sitting opposite me was on the committee as well and I am sure he would agree with me that we spent many, many hours listening to some very horrendous stories. I would also like to point out that I am one of only three women on this committee. Whilst it is personally rewarding for me to acknowledge that an increasing number of women are entering into the small business area, it is also good to know that in the main they are the people who are making a success of their businesses. And perhaps, without wanting to get involved in the gender bias argument, there is something here that our male colleagues could learn from women in business.

speaker: Mrs Johnston (Canning) (12.54 P.m.)
theText: I welcome the opportunity to speak today onThursday, 28 August 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 7361 The issues that this report seeks to address are based on a real commitment to secure a better deal for small business, which after all is very important in the revival of our economy. When handing down this report, I-along with other committee members-was very much aware of the need to keep to the terms of reference set out by the then minister for small business, the member for Forrest( Mr Prosser). The brief included investigating and reporting on unfair business conduct and dealings, as well as on the social and economic implications of major business conduct issues and their subsequent outcomes. I would suggest that this report is very timely. For far too long governments have failed to listen to the concerns of small business. Indeed, action to ensure that acceptable and fair business conduct is practised in Australia is now critically important for the successful future of this country. The committee received an overwhelming number of written and personal submissions. It would be less than honest to say that in most of those cases, small business operators did not ask for special protection or special treatment; they simply asked for the opportunity to get a fair deal. The evidence provided to the fair trading inquiry suggested that small businesses are often very frustrated by what they believe to be unfair commercial conduct when entering into business dealings with larger and more powerful companies. Such behaviour was alluded to as being present in all states of Australia, and, in particular, it centred around tenancy agreements, as we have already heard. Claims were made that major retailers were in a position to insist that developers exclude certain other retailers, and claims were made that franchise agreements were one-sided, more often than not in favour of the franchisor. In my own electorate of Canning, many constituents have complained to me about such practices. One retailer situated in a shopping centre was advised several years ago that the centre would be increased in size and revamped. It was suggested that he should be relocated. Since that time absolutely nothing has happened in that centre except that since then this small business operator has been on a monthly tenancy lease. I defy anybody in this room, let alone outside this House, to run a business on such a basis. In another case, a franchise operator was required to buy his stock through the franchisor. When the franchisee complained that part of the stock was inferior and damaged, he was told that he had no option to refuse it and it was suggested that he should sell his stock at a discount price-a ridiculous practice, I would suggest, for anybody to enter into. Another proprietor of a small business at a local shopping centre, neighbouring my electorate, advised the committee of action taken at the shopping centre against the property manager. She alleged gross overcharging in relation to variable outgoings and promotion levies. I have mentioned these examples as just a few of those that were brought to the attention of the committee as we travelled around the country hearing submissions, that were subsequently printed in the report that was handed down. The issue of retail tenancy is a matter of much contention, with a need for uniformity and security for tenants. I would suggest that this is a high priority. Predatory practices of big business are just not acceptable. The committee has recommended the need for contractual certainty to be paramount and for unfair and inequitable agreements to be done away with. It also recommended that a uniform tenancy code be developed to enable utilisation around the country and that this be underpinned in the Trade Practices Act. Establishing merchants' associations in shopping centres and regular statements of expenditure on outgoings and promotions was another recommendation which we believed to be highly desirable. 7362 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 28 August 1997 With regard to franchising, many people see buying a small business as an attractive option for securing a job and as an investment for their future. Indeed, some people decide to buy a business once they receive a redundancy payment. The committee's recommendation that proper business education and research are required when one embarks on franchising-or, for that matter, buying a business-is in my opinion very desirable and should be given a lot of thought. An argument was put before the committee that part IVA of section 51 of the Trade Practices Act 1974 should be amended to strengthen the stance on unfair conduct. The report outlines an amendment to the act that will incorporate a new provision dealing with unfair conduct in commercial transactions. Again, that is a recommendation that is very desirable. I believe that all businesses deserve a fair go. Small business should not be excluded from this. I concur with the previous speaker, the member for Cunningham, when he said that there are many small businesses that have been subjected to some dreadful exploitation and standover tactics by larger and more powerful businesses. We do need a balance in business practices. We do need fair play for all dealers. We do not want to have business conduct in this country which is skewed to one side or the other of the market. We all have to work harmoniously together and we should never really forget that it is the many thousands of small business operators that actually contribute to the well-being of this country. They are the people that provide the employment to our future generation. Unless we are able to find a balance in that situation, I am afraid that we will have some very nasty consequences to face. I therefore commend this report to the members here and to the government, and I do hope that we will find a fair balance in future trading for businesses. Finding a balance: towards fair trading in Australia, by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. Developing the report and the inquiry was a very educative process for me and I am thankful to a number of members of the committee who played a great role in the inquiry and assisted me to understand the problems that confront small business. I also thank those that came before us for their assistance in that education. One of the dismaying aspects of the whole inquiry process of this report was that so many of the people who came before us came very fearful of retribution. I have never been involved in an inquiry where so many people have asked for their submissions to be kept confidential and for their evidence to be given in camera. I think this reflects the type of atmosphere in which small business operates out in the real world, the way in which they feel concerned about the imbalance in power between small business and bigger business. I reflect on a person who operates a very successful small business in a shopping centre in my electorate. He came to me with a story that illustrated the problems that he had as a trader within that shopping centre and the problems that he had in operating a franchise. Incidentally he also has another arrangement, which is by way of licence, and there are problems with each of those arrangements. I said, 'You have a story that would be of great benefit to the committee. It would be very helpful if you could put it to the committee as a submission and then come forward and discuss that submission.' I was very distressed when a couple of weeks later I got the feedback that this gentleman, who could have been of great assistance to the inquiry, had decided not to go forward with his submission. He had decided not to take the offer to have a confidential submission or to come before the committee in camera basically because he was too scared of what it might
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Jenkins (Scullin) (1.04 P.m.)
theText: It is a pleasure to be able to speak to this report,Thursday, 28 August 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 7363 mean down the track for him in his dealings with not only the shopping centre managers but also those who hold the franchises. The sort of atmosphere that this inquiry was conducted in was in a way surprising. One of the principal people, a leading figure in one of the small business associations, in the last week of the last session said to me, 'What was your expectation? What did you think was the situation out there? Was it as bad as you thought it might be?' I had to admit to her that it was much worse. We held public hearings in all of the mainland capitals and a number of public hearings were held here in Canberra. The thing about the stories that we were told was that they were consistent right around Australia. Wherever we went, people came forward who had tried to put in place small businesses but had failed not just because they were perhaps lacking in skills but because their aspirations were crushed by those who were more powerful. In saying that, I stress that we have to acknowledge that, in the way in which the market operates, there will be people who will go to the wall no matter how well intentioned they are. This report is not talking about those cases: it is talking about the people who, because of the imbalance of power, were not given a chance from the start. Let us look at the recommendations that we have made about a uniform national retail tenancy code. We have tried, as a committee, to set down in the report recommendations and suggestions that deal with matters that should be covered in a uniform tenancy code to ensure that we redress the imbalance that is there between the tenants and the shopping centre owners and managers. The code would be about simple things such as the need for full disclosure when a tenant goes into a situation about matters that might relate to that person's tenancy. At the start of the inquiry, I thought the way things should operate was fairly straightforward and simple. I was shocked that, in practice, it did not occur, with great detriment and consequences to some of those people, who took up tenancies understanding certain details about the operation of the shopping centre, which they found had changed. They found that the basis for the number of people attending the shopping centre, and things like that, was overestimated. Professor Alan Millington, who operates out of one of the New South Wales universities, gave us evidence and, in his submission, he said: Above all, there is a need for retail property owners to accept that the success of their investments, and their shopping centres in partiCUlar, is ultimately completely dependent upon the success of tenants trading from them. Without successful retail tenants there would not be successful shopping centres. To have successful retail tenants owners must allow and assist them to prosper by working in partnership with them, rather than seeking to punish them for their success by ... persistent demands for ever higher rents irrespective of the ability of retailers to pay such rents. I thought that what Professor Millington said should have been self-evident. It seemed fairly logical that the relationship between the property owners and their tenants should be to the benefit of both. But in practice there were just too many stories from tenants about the behaviour that they had had to endure and we would wonder why it occurred. In so many cases in evidence brought before the committee, we wondered why there was this behaviour that forced tenants out, forced tenants to fail and forced tenants to go to the wall? When we spoke to the property owners and managers, of course, they said that the relationship should be as the professor stated, because it is obvious that, in a relatively symbiotic relationship between the two parties, both can succeed. But there were just too many 7364 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 28 August 1997 stories for the committee to ignore the fact that this was not the case. As the honourable member for Cunningham ( Mr Martin) has said, it was of concern when the peak body of the property owners and managers came out with their own study and suggested that we were not balanced in the way we treated the evidence and that, in some way, the inquiry lacked professionalism. I say to those people that, if the complaints that were put to us were not real-and I believe that the overwhelming majority are real and have substance--even if the complaints were based on perception, those property owners and managers have a big problem. As has been illustrated in this discussion and debate, you can still go to a shopping centre and quite easily get together a number of tenants that will come forward with stories of hardship and complaint. For instance, earlier in the month, the shadow minister went to a meeting at a shopping centre in my electorate. I was absent and could not be there. Thirty tenants came forward to describe to the shadow minister, the honourable member for Cunningham, the experiences they were having. Those experiences surrounded things that are difficult for property managers to handle. This particular shopping centre has undergone a three-phase increase in the amount of space that is available. It has meant that tenants have been shuffled around the place as this work has been done. But it has been the way in which those matters have been handled that has caused angst. For instance, simple things such as the parking arrangements for the shopping centre have been changed unilaterally. Longer term parking had been changed to short-term parking for people that were rushing in and out to the local supermarket. This affected neighbouring businesses because they relied on people coming into shopping centres, lingering and looking at the goods. There are all these intricacies that have to be taken into account and they can only be taken into account where there is a partnership. As has been said often in the discussion of this report-and it is one thing that I think the committee wants to emphasise-small businesses are not looking for special protection. They do not want anything particularly special in the arrangements that are put in place for them. They just want a fair deal. They want to be able to operate in the knowledge that they are getting that fair deal. The type of suggestions that we have put forward about changes to the Trade Practices Act and about legislating that people can take action where they believe there has been unfair conduct are important aspects of the way in which small businesses can feel that, through the legislative process, they have some backing. There has been some criticism of the actions of the former Labor government in regard to the matters that have been discussed in this report. A number of us would acknowledge that, yes, they are matters that perhaps should have been redressed. But given the emphasis that there is at the moment on voluntary codes of conduct, I think that Labor in government was willing to say, 'We will give them a go.' I have to say to you it has failed, and we are acknowledging that. The honourable member for Lowe( Mr Zammit) nods his head. He was somebody on the committee that emphasised that this was the case. He gave people the opportunity to say, 'Show us where they have succeeded.' of other members of the government on the committee, as the honourable member for Rankin( Mr Beddall) said when he spoke on the day of the tabling, has been very courageous in putting forward recommendations that might have been difficult for some of those in leadership

theText: He did a very good job.

speaker: Mr Jenkins
theText: He did a very good job and I acknowledge that. He, along with a numberThursday, 28 August 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 7365 and in executive positions within this government. Some recommendations would go against the orthodoxy of thinking of government. I appreciate that it is often difficult when you are in government when you know that you are out of step with those that are down in the ministerial end of this building. But the committee came up with a unanimous set of recommendations that I would hope the government considers closely. The opposition has indicated that they are quite willing to support legislation based on the recommendations in the report. I am pleased that that has been the indication by the opposition. This report was a very careful discussion and investigation of matters surrounding the way in which small business is treated. The urgency of these matters is illustrated time and time again. At the moment, the people that have franchises with Shell have concerns because the arrangements that had been made about the pricing of fuel from Shell have been unilaterally changed. If the franchising code had been working properly, this would not have been allowed. But what we need to see is a legislative basis for franchising so that the codes of conduct can be enforced by legislation. We need some arrangements whereby the franchisors have to register so that the franchisees can comfortably feel that they do have some legitimate basis that will give them protection. I hope that, in the next few weeks, when the minister discloses the government's reaction to this report, they accept the recommendations that have been handed down by the report. (Time expired) Main Committee on the report of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, Finding a balance: towards fair trading in Australia. I must say that this is one of the most balanced reports I have ever had the pleasure of being part of. It comes from a committee of 15 people, all of whom are dedicated to trying to find a way to assist small businesses to have a fair go, which I think is one of the major Australian traits. I have been a member of parliament for some 18 months in the federal sphere, and for about 12 years before that in the state sphere. I have been involved by shopkeepers and tenantsreluctantly, on my part, but with no choice but to represent my constituents. If ever there was a tragedy of strong arm tactics being employed by those who have all the aces in the pack, this is one of the cases that I think should not have been allowed to go on for as long as they have. The opposition has said that it gave voluntary codes of conduct a go. I appreciate that, but it has not worked. One of the questions we asked of all the people who came before us and who recommended the continuation of a voluntary code of conduct was: 'Name one industry where the voluntary code of conduct has operated.' They could not, satisfactorily. No-one could, because it just does not work. There is no doubt that you need to underpin it by legislation, and that is one of the recommendations. Where a retail tenant or a shopkeeper in a major shopping centre feels that, for whatever reason, they have been treated in an unfair and unconscionable way, there is nothing available to them, to fight back, other than to take legal action. But we all know that they cannot do that without going bankrupt. They just cannot take on the major shopping centres, with the tremendous facilities available to them-unlimited amounts of money, legal advice, and so on-and walk away without being hurt very badly or ending up being bankrupt, which is just as bad. I recall a particular instance in one of my shopping centres, where I came to know the owner of the shopping centre quite well and I found that person to be a very reasonable person. He

speaker: Mr Zammit (Lowe) (1.19 P.m.)
theText: I am very pleased to rise to enter the debate in this7366 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 28 August 1997 is not an Australian national, and he had to leave the running of the company in the hands of a real estate agent who claimed to have management expertise in dealing with difficult situations. I struck up a relationship with this person. I had to bypass the managers of the shopping centre because I was getting nowhere with them. I was fortunate in that he was very willing to listen to me and very willing to come to some agreement. In some instances, that just could not happen. I well recall getting a phone call from the centre manager in one of my shopping centres. In fact, I mentioned publicly in the inquiry that this person contacted me. She said, 'Your request' -for whatever it was; I do not remember the exact matter'has been denied.' I said, 'I'm not very happy about that, because I think what you did was unjust.' She said, 'But let me warn you. You could be up for very serious charges. You mayor may not have seen the New South Wales act that specifically stops someone from entering as a third party into a dispute between two other parties in a shopping centre arrangement.' I must say that I found that intimidating. I found it insulting, in the implied threat that she was going to arrange to take legal action against me for representing my constituents. I recall receiving a phone call from the company involved. They apologised for any such threat, but they claimed that the threat was not made. I said, 'It's your word against mine, but I would suggest that you have it investigated.' They wrote back to me after about a week and they talked around the subject, but they did not deny that I had been threatened. I then phoned the general manager of the company and said, 'I've got my own advice. If you try and stop me ever again from carrying out my duties as an elected member of parliament, then I will take my own appropriate action. That sort of action is not the sort of thing that would be useful to you or to me, or to the parliament, but you leave me no choice.' If these people can act towards me in the way that they have, you can imagine how much more intimidating it must be for the shopkeepers and the tenants. Let me give you specific examples of some of the things that have occurred. I know of a person who, in a shopping centre, owned a delicatessen-type shop and was selling cheeses and ham and all the sorts of things that are sold in a delicatessen. The shopping centre allowed the extension of a supermarket and allowed it in such a way that, within three metres of the shop, there was a delicatessen-type set-up. I suppose you can say that competition is competition, but I say up to a point. If there were any goodwill involved from the centre management, they would have said to the supermarket, 'You can go ahead and sell all the things that are sold at a delicatessen but not so close to the entrance of this other shop.' But they refused to do that. When I asked them about that they said, 'We have no right to intervene in how a supermarket runs its business.' ThenI pointed out to the supermarket that on an hourly basis they would put specials out to undercut that little shop that had been there for 15 years. As soon as the little shop put their specials out, within an hour the supermarket would put their specials out, undercutting them. I refer to the recommendations that the committee inquiring into fair trading brought down. I must say that it was very unique that we were totally united in our view on how to deal with this issue. The recommendations are to allow all little shops like the one I mentioned to do something about unfair and unconscionable conduct-which no doubt is what it is. Of course, the thing that holds these shops back is that they cannot go to court. First of all, they have reached a stage in their lives when they are having difficulty paying the rent and having difficulty meeting the competition. The last thing they can do is find another $40,000 Thursday, 28 August 1997 MAIN COMMlITEE 7367 or $50,000 to go to court. Even if they went to court and won they would have to fight the shopping centre, which would say, 'We think we've been unfairly treated by the court, and we'll appeal.' That means that the small shops would have to find another $40,000 or $50,000, and of course they just do not have that sort of money to fight back. This is a very complex situation that is facing Australians. I want to refer to a couple of specific recommendations that I believe are extremely important. One is recommendation 2.3, regarding dispute resolution. The committee has recommended low cost mediation. In other words, the committee has said, 'Let's not run off to court all the time; let's put in place a mechanism whereby an aggrieved party can go to someone and say, "You're an independent arbitrator; would you arbitrate between us?''' We request that, whichever side the arbitrator comes down against, the arbitrator do the right thing without anyone having to go to court. We want to stop Australia heading down the path of some other nations of the world where they go to court at the drop of a hat to resolve difficulties that they may encounter. I think that that is one of the most important things that the committee has recommended-to allow low cost dispute resolution. Also, the committee has said that it is very important that, in the event that the dispute resolution is not satisfactorily resolved, there be some mechanism by which an aggrieved party can go to a court without it costing them an arm and a leg-in other words, it does not do away with their right to defend themselves against something that is seen by them to be unfair and unconscionable conduct. That is not available to them at present. I think that that is one of the most important recommendations that we need to have a look at. The other thing that I want to raise is the question of uniform retail tenancy acts and a contract that is uniform throughout Australia. With all of these different jurisdictions-six states and two territories-having their different rules and regulations and contracts, it is very important that there be one contract Australia-wide that everyone understands. People want to know how it can be used to resolve difficulties. They want the contract to be clear so that nothing is left out that may be used against a person who, unwittingly, may have signed a contract. We had solicitors appear before the committee who admitted to us that despite all of their training, the thing that concerned them was not what was in the contract, but what was not in the contract. That was the difficulty. They admitted to us that they were not able to advise their clients satisfactorily because it was not just what you read, it was what was not in it that could cause grave difficulty. I also want to talk about the lack of relocation clauses that apply to retail tenants. One of the things that concerns a lot of retail tenants is the fear of relocation. A shopping centre manager can go to a shopkeeper who has been there for a very long time and say, 'We are going to move you.' They might reply, 'Well, if I have to, I have to.' The manager then says, 'You don't have a choice; you have to because that is the decision.' Then the shopkeeper asks, 'What does it involve?' and the manager says, 'We're going to move you around the back, around the comer.' The shopkeeper then says, 'But no-one will know where we will be,' and they say, 'Well, that's too bad.' The shopkeeper finally asks, 'What about the fit-outs?' and the reply is, 'That's too bad. You're going to have to pay for the fit-outs as well.' That can be a tremendous drain on a retail tenant, and in m<'.ny instances it virtually destroys them. It is not just the relocation of the shop from where they are known to another place 7368 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 28 August 1997 where they are not known and which is perhaps difficult to find; they also have to find the money to do up the shop to the satisfaction of the centre management. I feel that this is a very important step that the committee has taken in outlining all of the difficulties involved in running a small business. I feel that the recommendations that are made here are very sensible and moderate, and they are going to help small and medium sized businesses tremendously. They are also going to help property owners because they will be able to have some stability in the way they run their businesses. There will not be the threat of legal action back and forth on both sides. I am very pleased to have contributed to this debate. Debate (on motion by Mr Slipper) adjourned.
